awd_titl_txt: Partner association and adaptation in the Dictyostelium-Burkholderia proto-farming symbiosis
awd_abstract_narration:
Members of different species sometimes associate and adapt to each other. Sometimes the associations are mutually beneficial, as in many of the bacteria associated with the human gut. In this work, the investigators will explore the mostly beneficial interactions in a much simpler system where several bacterial species are carried in the gut of an amoeba. The bacteria gain by being transported to new localities in amoeba spores while the amoeba gains by being able to seed out populations of food bacteria in new areas. The result is a sort of primitive farming. The investigators will first explore how selection works on this system using experiments to test new theory that could also be applied to more complex systems. Second, they will explore how the partnerships are formed. Are the partners attracted to each other and are particularly good food bacteria favored? Finally, the investigators will determine many of the amoeba and bacterial genes that control this interaction, exploiting the fact that both partners can be genetically manipulated. The students and post-doctoral individuals in this project will gain valuable training in important areas like genomics. The investigators will also impact high school students through on-campus workshops, undergrads and grads via a blog on being an academic, and the local community via an innovative science booth at the Ferguson farmer's market.

The social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum and two clades of Burkholderia bacteria engage in a remarkable microbiome-like symbiosis. The Burkholderia gain dispersal inside amoeba spores and also induce carriage of food bacteria that are released after spore dispersal to seed new food crops for the amoebas. This model system for symbiosis exploits short lifespans, small genomes, genetically manipulability, and other advantages. The PIs will use a new theoretical framework to estimate components of selection for both partners (Aim 1). This framework draws on analogies with kin selection theory and promises to be similarly useful.  Second, they will explore partner association, testing how Burkholderia and Dictyostelium find each other, whether they succeed at choosing beneficial partners, and whether there is preferential association with beneficial food bacteria.  Finally, they will discover many of the genes involved in the symbiosis and how they have evolved (Aim 3). Insertional mutant libraries of both partners will be constructed, put through various selection regimes, and sequenced to determine frequency changes that will identify relevant genes.

Public summary

 

One of the great surprises in biology in the last few decades is how dependent organisms are on each other. This was already known at obvious levels: plants get energy from the sun but others eat plants, animals, or other organisms. What is surprising is how intertwined different living organisms can be. So much of life depends and cooperates with other forms of life, but natural selection will favor genetically distinct individuals to maximize their own interests. How is this compatible with cooperation? The short answer is when the interests of both converge, cooperation will easily evolve. In practice it can be hard to tell what is cooperative and what is competitive. On a microbial scale how do we tell a cooperative symbiont from an infective one? This is important for bacteria can be both beneficial and harmful.

This project studied a particular case of entwined lives: those of a social amoeba and certain bacteria that live inside it. The amoeba is Dictyostelium discoideum. It has an unusual social cycle. When the amoebas starve, a consequence of not finding enough bacteria to eat, they aggregate by the thousands and ultimately form a little fruiting body with a stalk made up of dead cells with living spores awaiting dispersal on top.

The surprise was that three species of Paraburkholderia bacteria could be carried along in this process. This means the interests of the host and symbiont could be quite entwined. We did some mathematics and modeling to understand exactly what this might be like and call the relationship a kith coefficient.

We did experiments where we cured the amoebas with antibiotics so they no longer carried the bacteria. Then we reintroduced either the bacteria the amoebas had originally been collected in the soil with or other bacteria collected from other amoebas. We predicted that those that naturally occurred together would do best together. It turned out that there was not a lot of specificity in who did best with whom.

We used another way to understand the relationship between amoebas and bacteria. We exposed bacteria to the liquid in which the amoebas had grown and saw that the bacteria swam towards the amoeba water. This means they were attracted to the amoebas, something that is consistent with the bacteria getting a benefit from being with the amoebas. One of the benefits could be the bacteria are carried by the amoebas. Since amoebas can be a place harmful bacteria could hide from control agents, it is important to understand this relationship.

Besides the interactions between the amoebas and their symbiont bacteria, there are also interactions with bacteria that the amoebas can eat. They cannot digest their symbiont bacteria, but it turns out that those bacteria facilitate carriage of food bacteria. Most interestingly, the amoebas are most likely to carry food bacteria when they are in a place with few food bacteria. Understanding this three-way relationship is important because it means bacteria that are not symbionts of amoebas might take advantage of that relationship and get protection from the amoebas.

We are also interested in the genes that are important for relationships of bacteria to amoebas. We used two ways to study this. First, we sequenced the genomes of the bacteria and discovered that the genomes of two of the three species of Paraburkholderia had about half as many genes as relatives that were not symbionts. This is an indication of their dependence on the amoebas. Second, we used special techniques to break certain genes and see how that changed the interaction of the bacteria with the amoeba host. We hoped to find genes that when broken turned the inedible symbiont into an edible food bacterium. We found lots of genes important in this process that we are studying.

This research did not only find interesting things about amoebas and bacteria. Doing the research taught a lot of students about the process of scientific discovery and communication. The research involved three postdoctoral scholars, all women. It involved five graduate students, two women and one Hispanic man. It involved nine undergraduates, five of whom are women. One of the undergraduates is Hispanic and three are African American.

We communicated the results of our research in many publications and also by giving talks at different universities and national and international meetings.

We involved the community in science by hosting an activity at the Ferguson Farmers? Market one Saturday a month. Our activities consist of simple games that teach both something cool about science and also how the scientific method works. One of our activities is featured in an article we wrote for American Biology Teacher. We also write a blog designed to explain how to become a biology professor, https://sociobiology.wordpress.com.
